title-group.article-title: Effect of thread tension on mechanical performance of stitched glass fibre-reinforced polymer laminates –experimental study

contrib-group.aff: Department of Materials Technology, Faculty of Materials Engineering and Metallurgy, Silesian University of Technology, Poland

author-notes.corresp: Mateusz Koziol, Department of Materials Technology, Faculty of Materials Engineering and Metallurgy, Silesian University of Technology, ul. Krasinskiego 8, 40-019 Katowice, Poland. Email: Mateusz.Koziol@polsl.pl

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: This article presents the results of interlaminar shear and flexural tests of polyester resin – glass fibre laminates made from the preforms unstitched and stitched by various thread tensions: low, medium and high. The laminates were impregnated using resin transfer moulding method. The interlaminar shear and flexural tests were conducted by loading parallel and transverse to the stitch lines. Interlaminar shear strength, flexural strength and flexural modulus were obtained. Deformation extent of the reinforcing structure of the stitched laminate increases with the increase in the thread tension and causes decrease in the flexural strength and modulus. However, the increase in the thread tension offers improvement in the interlaminar shear strength. Optimization of changes in the flexural properties and the interlaminar shear strength with the thread tension showed that an operation of stitching of the reinforcing preforms should be conducted by low or medium stitching thread tension (approximately 3–9 N).

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The study is to evaluate the improvement in translaminar strength and simultaneous deterioration of in-plane performance of stitched glass fibre-reinforced polymer (GFRP) laminate in dependence on stitching thread tension. The mechanical properties have been tested in interlaminar shear tests (interlaminar strength) and static flexural tests (in-plane properties). Practical aim of the study is to work out new guidelines and indications for manufacturers who use or plan to use a stitching technique in composite technology. This article supplements the global base of experimental results for stitched laminates and is a continuation of the earlier study conducted by Koziol.1 Results of the analysis may also be useful for modification of theoretical models.

Although the study focuses only on one type of a stitch (plain stitch) and on one type of a laminate structure (0/90 layout), the obtained results are practically valuable – described trends are usable also for other stitches and structures.

Application of 8- and 10-layer thick laminates within the study emerges from earlier researches conducted on such structures. This study is a continuation of these researches. Examination of the 8- and 10-layer laminates is to show how the slight (about 20%) change in thickness affects the behaviour of the laminate after stitching.

sec.title: Theoretical background
sec.p: A delamination crack occurs within FRP laminate structure usually after local impact. After occurrence it develops due to working stresses of the laminate, leading to reduction in load capacity or even to destruction of the material. Such behaviour has been studied among others by Prichard and Hogg,2 Liu,3 Su,4 Chung et al.,5 Jang et al.,6 Cantwell and Morton7 and Hosur et al.8 The problem of delamination cracking reduces an application potential of the laminates. A number of solutions have been proposed to limit the formation and development of delamination cracks in the laminates. Two groups of methods may be distinguished: (a) the methods concerning improvement in properties of the components and a connection between them – mainly improvement in crack resistance of the matrix; the current instance may be the study by Seyhan et al.9 and (b) the methods including modifications of a reinforcement architecture – mainly production of three-dimensional laminates – studied among others by Mayadas et al.,10 Chan,11 Partridge and Cartie12 and Baral et al.13 One of the most popular method of the delamination development reduction is stitching of reinforcing layers with a stiff and strong thread (glass, polyaramide and carbon). Stitching is also the main method for assembling of the preforms. Quality and deformability of the stitched preforms is sufficient enough for production of primary components – even in aviation – what has been confirmed among others by Weimar and Mitschang,14 Beier et al.15 and Lomov et al.16–18 Exemplary industrial applications of the stitched laminates are aircraft wing panels, which have been studied by Brown19 and parts of fuselages of small naval vessels – patrol crafts and submarines, studdied among others by Mouritz et al.,20 Rhee et al.,21 Mouritz22–24 and Shah Khan and Mouritz.25 Industrial fan blades (especially more than 1 m long) may be the one of the potential areas of use for the stitched preforms. Also special piping systems, like braided structure based pipes for chemical industry studied by Hufenbach et al.,26 have a potential to apply stitching to improve a strength of joints. The new application is the multilayer armour-plate for modern armoured vehicles.

The main effect of stitching thread is bridging of initiated interlaminar crack and prevent it from developing widely – it has been defined by Jain and Mai.27 However, during stitching operation damages and misalignments appear within the reinforcing structure leading to significant decrease in load capacity of the laminate in in-plane directions. One of the main structure disturbances caused by stitching is a deformation from thread tension (tightening of the reinforcing layers together) (Figure 1). Figure 1.
Deformation of a laminate reinforcing structure caused by stitching threads: (a) stitched laminate; (b) unstitched laminate (for comparison); (c) planes indicating the lines (grooves) of deformation; and (d) schema of machine plain stitch.

Only a few studies have been performed towards the effect of structure deformation on mechanical properties of stitched laminates. They had rather theoretical character – especially inspiring seems the study by Mouritz and Cox.28 However, numerous works have appeared concerning the other types of stitching-arisen defects, as resin pockets or thread knot presence, among others by Mouritz,23 Havley,29 Liu,30 Morales,31 Palmer et al.,32 Vandermey et al.33 and Velmurugan and Solaimurugan.34

sec.title: Experimental procedure
sec.p: Interlaminar shear tests and three-point bending tests were performed on laminates reinforced with plain weave E-glass fabric produced by Krosglas® Krosno, Poland. It was originally treated with vinylsilane finish preparation suitable for polyester and vinylester resins. Areal weight of the fabric was 350 g/m2 and a lay-up was 0/90 for all specimens. 8- and 10-layer reinforcing preforms were prepared (total areal weight as follows: 2800 and 3500 g/m2) by edge basting. Before impregnation with the resin, part of the preforms was stitched with Kevlar® 50 thread supplied by DUPONT, 50 tex linear density, textile finish treatment. Plain stitch (Figure 1(d)) by about 5 stitches/cm2 stitch density – 4 mm in stitch length, 5 mm in stitch spacing, was used. Stitching was performed on Lucznik 834 half-industrial sewing machine. In order to obtain the preforms with different deformation extents, stitching was conducted by various thread tensions: 1 (low), 6 (medium) and 10 (high) thread tension units (ttu). It was measured with use of mechanical hand force gauge that 1 ttu is about 1.5 N. one unit of tension was unavaliable on the machine and part of the preforms were stitched manually. However, machine plain stitch and all other conditions were kept.

Impregnation process was conducted by resin transfer moulding method. Estromal 14 polyester resin produced by ERG Pustkow, Poland, was used as the matrix. Luperox (solution of methylethylketone peroxide in dibutyl phthalate) was used as the catalyst in amount of 1.5% by weight. Saturated composite panels 210 × 280 mm2 were cured in room temperature for 24 h and post-cured in 55℃ for 6 h. Test specimens were cut parallel and transverse to the stitch lines (Figure 2(a)). The laminates were, respectively: 2 (8-layer) and 2.4 (10-layer) mm thick. Fibre volume fraction in the composites (unstitched and stitched as well) ranged between 50.5% and 51.5% – it was determined by mass comparison method (dry preform sheet compared with equivalent laminate segment after curing). Figure 2.
Tested specimens – shapes and dimensions.

Interlaminar shear tests were conducted by notched beam tensile method, on the Instron 4469 machine, by travelling speed of 0.5 mm/min. Load cell capacity was 5 kN and accuracy of measurement was 0.1 N. Nine specimens were put to the test for each measure point. The tests were conducted according to ASTM D3846 standard.35 Interlaminar shear strength was evaluated according to equation (1) (1)τmax=Pmaxd·wMPa where τmax is interlaminar shear strength, MPa, Pmax is maximum load reached during the test, N, d is distance between the notches (Figure 2(b)), mm and w is width of the specimen, mm.

Specimens for the tests were prepared by machining and were 200 ± 2 mm long and 20 ± 1 mm wide. The distance between notches was 20 ± 0.5 mm for all specimens. A radius of notch end curvature was 0.5 ± 0.01 mm. For all the specimens the rule was kept that depth of the notch equals at least ½ of specimen thickness plus 5%. It warrants that the notches ends always ‘overlap’. Anti-buckling steel plates were used. There were not attempts made to align the notches with the stitch length/spacing. Three-point bending tests were conducted according to PN-EN ISO 14125 standard36 on Instron 4469 machine, by travelling speed of 10 mm/min and bearers spacing L = 60 mm. Load cell capacity was 5 kN and accuracy of measurement was 0.1 N. Seven specimens were put to the test for each measure point. The specimens were 80 ± 2 mm long and 20 ± 1 mm wide.

Average angle of fibre strands deflection around the stitch point (α) was measured. It helps to explain the anisotropy of mechanical properties in stitched laminates and the effect of thread tension on their mechanical performance. The measurements were done by analysis of microscopic photographs. Series of the photographs for various cross sections of stitched laminates were done with use of NIKON SMZ 1000 microscope (total magnification 96×) equipped with photo camera. Six photos randomly taken from various areas of the laminate for each cross section: along the stitch line – exactly on stitch ‘cell’ (Figure 3(b) – A), along the stitch lines – exactly between two stitch points (Figure 3(c) – B) and transverse to the stitch lines – exactly between two stitch-points (Figure 3(d) – C) were done. The photo-sets were done for the laminates stitched by low, medium and high thread tensions. Figure 3.
Representative cross sections in stitched laminate: (a) unstitched laminate; (b) the stitch ‘cell’ along the stitch line (A); (c) the line of the stitch-points exactly between two stitch lines (B); and (d) the stitch lines ‘cut’ exactly between two stitch-points (C).

The procedure of α angle determination has been already introduced in the earlier study by Koziol.1 The angle between straight line parallel to laminate surface and the straight line joining the highest (B in Figure 4) and the lowest (E in Figure 4) points of visible deflected fibre strand was taken as the measure. Figure 4.
Method of determination of fibre strands deflection angle α occurred from thread tension: (a) visualization of the method – based on former study by Koziol1 (b) exemplary photograph of laminate cross section along the stitch lines; and (c) location of B and E points in the magnified photograph.

sec.title: Results of mechanical tests
sec.p:
The results of the interlaminar shear strength τmax vs thread tension are shown in Figure 5. τmax is visibly higher for the stitched laminates in comparison to the unstitched. Such behaviour has been observed by numerous researchers – among others by Liu,3 Mayadas et al.,10 Jain and Mai27 and Koziol.1 Moreover, it is clearly visible that τmax goes up with thread tension (Figure 5). Figure 5.
The results of interlaminar shear strength τmax obtained for unstitched and equivalent laminates stitched by various thread tensions: (a) 8-layer laminate and (b) 10-layer laminate.
W – load direction parallel to the stitch lines and P – load direction transverse to the stitch lines.

The increase in the interlaminar shear strength of stitched laminates, in comparison to the unstitched, reaches 56.4% for high thread tension and the parallel load direction. Approximations of τmax vs thread tension relation were made in accordance with equation (2) (2)τmax=AT+BMPa where A is the first approximation constant, MPa ttu, B the second approximation constant, MPa, and T the thread tension, ttu; ttu the thread tension unit: 1 ttu ≈ 1.5 N.

The approximation curves are placed on diagrams in Figure 3. The obtained approximation parameters A and B are presented in Table 1. Table 1.
The approximation constants obtained for interlaminar shear strength vs thread tension by parallel and transverse load directions to the stitch lines
Number of layers and loading direction to the stitch lines A (MPa ttu) B (MPa)
8-layer – parallel loading direction −6.1 18.8
8-layer – transverse loading direction −4.5 16.8
10-layer – parallel loading direction −5.6 18
10-layer – transverse loading direction −4.4 16.6
t
tu: thread tension unit.
Function type selection and optimization of A and B parameters were made with use of LAB-FIT software available in the Internet site.37 This software was used for all approximations within the study.

Slightly bigger increases in the τmax have been observed for the load parallel to the stitch lines, in comparison to the transverse load. The disparity value increases with the increase in thread tension. It is probably caused by contribution of the threads in a transfer of the tensile load during the interlaminar shear tests. Efficiency of such behaviour is evidently dependent on thread tension during stitching process. Tight thread makes difficult the reciprocal movement (shear) of reinforcing layers by relatively low strain (much lower than the shear-break strain). Weakly strained thread starts to strengthen later (just before the shear-brake strain). Similar progress and slope are visible in the interlaminar shear curves of the laminate loaded parallel and transverse to the stitch lines as well when it is stitched by low thread tension (Figure 6). At the same time, the curves corresponding with the laminate stitched by high thread tension show clearly visible difference in the slope. Figure 6.
The representative curves of static interlaminar shear for both, unstitched and stitched laminates, loaded parallel and transverse to the stitch lines: (a) laminate stitched by low stitch tension force (1 ttu) and (b) laminate stitched by high stitch tension force (10 ttu).
N – unstitched, W – load direction parallel to the stitch lines and P – load direction transverse to the stitch lines. ttu: thread tension units.

The results of the bending tests: flexural strength σf and flexural modulus Ef vs thread tension are shown in Figures 5 and 6. The σf and Ef as well are visibly lower for stitched laminates, than for the unstitched. It is in accordance with the earlier investigation results, among others by Mouritz23 and Hosur et al.8 However, σf and Ef of stitched laminates undergo increasing drop, relative to the unstitched ones, with increase in thread tension (Figures 7 and 8). Figure 7.
The results of flexural strength σf obtained for unstitched and equivalent laminates stitched by various stitch tensions: (a) 8-layer laminate and (b) 10-layer laminate.
W – load direction parallel to the stitch lines and P – load direction transverse to the stitch lines.
Figure 8.
The results of flexural elastic modulus Ef obtained for unstitched and equivalent laminates stitched by various stitch tensions: (a) 8-layer laminate and (b) 10-layer laminate.
W – load direction parallel to the stitch lines and P – load direction transverse to the stitch lines.

The results of σf and Ef vs thread tension were approximated according to the relation y = xA + B. It is given in applicable form as equation (3) (3)y=(-TT0)A·C0+B where y is the property of the laminate (σf, Ef), MPa, A the first approximation constant, B the second approximation constant, MPa, T the thread tension, ttu, T0 the first reference constant: T0 = 1 ttu and C0 the second reference constant: C0 = 1 MPa; ttu the thread tension unit: 1 ttu ≈ 1.5 N.

The approximation curves are placed in Figures 7 and 8. The obtained approximation parameters A and B are presented in Tables 2 and 3. Table 2.
The approximation constants obtained for flexural strength σf vs thread tension by parallel and transverse load directions to the stitch lines
Number of layers and loading direction to the stitch lines A B (MPa)
8-layer – parallel loading direction 1.41 411
8-layer – transverse loading direction 1.99 401
10-layer – parallel loading direction 1.36 415
10-layer – transverse loading direction 2 398
Table 3.
The approximation constants obtained for flexural modulus Ef vs thread tension by parallel and transverse load directions to the stitch lines
Number of layers and loading direction to the stitch lines A B (MPa)
8-layer – parallel loading direction 3.06 20,620
8-layer – transverse loading direction 3.76 20,250
10-layer – parallel loading direction 3.75 19,970
10-layer – transverse loading direction 3.48 20,100
The obtained A constants confirmed that σf changes significantly less intensively with thread tension than Ef (approximately twice A-value).

Representative curves of static bending for both, unstitched and stitched laminates, are given in Figure 9. Figure 9.
The representative curves of static bending for both, unstitched and stitched laminates, bent parallel and transverse to the stitch lines: (a) laminate stitched by low stitch tension (1 ttu); (b) laminate stitched by medium stitch tension (6 ttu); and (c) laminate stitched by high stitch tension (10 ttu). ttu: thread tension units.

The σf and Ef show particularly large drops by loading transverse to the stitch lines. It comes out from presence of the stitch lines along the bending direction. The stitch lines become the grooves of ‘privileged’ bending. The grooves also occur into direction transverse to the stitch lines between stitching points (Figure 3(c)). However, the stitch lines cause much larger deformation of the structure, because of pulling tight the layers (stitch creation). For low thread tension it is visible that the bending curves of the laminates loaded parallel and transverse to the stitch lines are very close to each other (Figure 9(a)). The laminates stitched with medium and high thread tensions show larger and larger difference between the parallel- and transverse- load curves (Figure 9(b) and (c)). The anisotropy obviously increases with thread tension.

Very similar trends are visible for 8- and 10-layer laminates (Figures 7 and 8). Only by loading transverse to the stitch lines and high thread tension, slightly larger decreases occur for 10-layer laminate. It may result from bigger relative decrease in section modulus – 10-layer laminate is thicker and have bigger ‘potential’ for thickness loss.

sec.title: The results of the fibre strands deflection measurements
sec.p:
The average strand deflection angle α-values are shown in Figure 10. Main theoretical assumption to the α measurement purpose is a fact that the disturbance of a parallelism of the reinforcing fibres to the load direction causes deterioration in mechanical performance of the laminate. Analysis of such effect was done among others by Kelly.38 Figure 10.
The values of deformation angle α for three deformation directions of the reinforcing structure by various thread tensions: A – deformation along the stitch-lines on a stitch-line; B – deformation along the stitch-lines between two stitch-lines; and C – deformation transverse to the stitch-lines, see Figure 3.

Exemplary photographs of cross sections of the laminates stitched with various thread tension are shown in Figure 11. Figure 11.
Exemplary photographs of cross sections of the 10-layer laminates stitched with various thread tensions: (a) 1 ttu; (b) 6 ttu; (c) 10 ttu; and (d) 1 ttu – failure of machine stitching.
ttu – the thread tension unit: 1 ttu ≈ 1.5 N.

Significant differences in the deflection of reinforcing fibre strands along and transverse to the stitch lines were observed. However, average deformation of the reinforcing structure is significantly larger ‘from the stitch line’ (Figure 3(d)) than ‘from the stitch’ (Figure 3(c)).

The results of the α angle have been approximated in dependence on thread tension, according to equation (4) (4)α=AT+B where A is the first approximation constant, (°) ttu, B is the second approximation constant, °, T is the thread tension, ttu; ttu is the thread tension unit: 1 ttu ≈ 1.5 N.

The obtained approximation constants are presented in Table 4. Table 4.
The approximation constants obtained for the reinforcing fibre strands deformation angle (α) vs thread tension for three deformation directions of a stitched laminate
Deformation directions variety 8 layers 10 layers
A (°/units) B (°) A (°/units) B (°)
Deformation along the stitch-lines on a stitch-line (A)a −10.5 24 −12.7 28
Deformation along the stitch-lines between two stitch-lines (B)b −3.4 12.9 −5.1 14.8
Deformation transverse to the stitch-lines (C)c −6.8 18.5 −6.6 21.2
a
See Figure 3(b). b
See Figure 3(c). c
See Figure 3(d).

The variability in the α angle along and transverse to the stitch lines is most likely reason of the anisotropy in mechanical properties of a stitched laminate. However, the intensity of anisotropic changes (depth of the deformation grooves) strongly depends on thread tension.

Also, other authors referred changes in mechanical performance of stitched laminates to the angle of fibre strands deflection. However, they rather concerned the in-plane misalignment – such research appeared among others in the study by Wu and Wang39 and Mauritz and Cox.28,40

sec.title: Optimization of the thread tension
sec.p: Increase in thread tension causes deterioration in the flexural properties of a stitched laminate. However, decrease in thread tension improves the τmax of the laminate (Figure 1, Table 1). In addition, most of sewing machines need relatively high thread tension to sew the thick fibrous preforms without failures (Figure 11(d)). Even the machines having special construction do not guarantee to avoid the troubles with thread tension – it was studied by Kresse.41 Therefore, prior criteria from among the in-plane and translaminar mechanical properties must be established and optimization must be done for each stitched laminate application.

Optimization of the σf, Ef and τmax has been undertaken within the study. Simple method has been used, consisting in:
Determination and approximation of the percentage changes in the σf, Ef and τmax with thread tension.
Imposition of the σf and Ef approximation curves to individual diagrams with the τmax approximation curve.
Taking of the curves intersections as the optimum for individual cases.

The optimization results are given in Figure 12. Figure 12.
Optimization of the σf and Ef with the τmax percentage changes with increasing thread tension: (a) the σf with the τmax optimization for the 8-layer laminate; (b) the Ef with the τmax optimization for the 8-layer laminate; (c) the σf with the τmax optimization for the 10-layer laminate; and (d) the Ef with the τmax optimization for the 10-layer laminate.
W – load direction parallel to the stitch lines and P – load direction transverse to the stitch lines.

The following optimum values of the thread tension have been settled:
The σf: 1.5 ttu (parallel to the stitch lines) and 0.5 ttu (transverse to the stitch lines) for the 8- and the 10-layer laminates.
The Ef: 5.5 ttu (parallel to the stitch lines) for the 8- and 10-layer laminates, 2 ttu for the 8- and 3 ttu for the 10-layer laminates (transverse to the stitch lines).

The results of the optimization indicate that comparable decrease (about 11–27%) in flexural properties and in interlaminar shear strength as well, occurs by low or medium thread tension. It should be asserted that high thread tension is usable only in cases of application when especially high delamination toughness is required.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p:
The performed research enables to express the following conclusions:
Increase in stitching thread tension causes improvement in interlaminar shear strength (τmax) of stitched laminate. The τmax shows visibly intensive growth up to the thread tension of about 9 N.
Increase in stitching thread tension causes deterioration of in-plane mechanical performance (σf and Ef) of stitched laminate. The σf and Ef show visibly intensive decrease for thread tension higher than about 6 N.
Deformation extent of the reinforcing structure of stitched laminate increases with increase in thread tension. The deformation takes the form of grooves along which the reinforcing lay-up becomes thinner. Such grooves occur the lines of privileged bending.
Mechanical anisotropy of stitched laminate (for σf, Ef and τmax) parallel and transverse to the stitch lines increases with the increase in thread tension.
Optimization of changes in: σf, Ef and τmax with increasing thread tension showed that the operation of preforms stitching should be conducted by thread tension ranging from 3 to 9 N.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This study is partially financed by Polish National Science Centre within a scope of the project nr 6286/B/T02/2011/40.

sec.title: Conflicts of interest
sec.p: None declared.
